awd_titl_txt: P2C2: High-resolution dynamical and statistical downscaling of El Nino Southern Oscillation (ENSO) response in proxy-critical locations across the tropical Pacific
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to use an atmosphere-only mesoscale weather forecasting model (WRF) to downscale general circulation model (GCM) outputs in order to investigate how local and regional climate in the tropical Pacific region respond to different patterns (or flavors) of El Nino Southern Oscillation (ENSO) from the last Glacial maximum to present. The downscaled GCM outputs will then be compared to ENSO proxy-records where they exist (Galapagos, eastern Pacific coasts, Line Islands and Palau) in order to quantitatively assess the diversity of ENSO impacts in these locations. This approach considers how the unique terrain and the local aspect of weather and climate modulate the complexity of ENSO-induced regional atmospheric circulation. The ultimate goal will be a better interpretation of ENSO proxy records and therefore a deeper understanding of ENSO variability through model-data comparison.

The potential Broader Impacts include: 1) a suite of downscaled climate variables with state-of-the-art models (e.g. precipitation, soil moisture, temperature); 2) a database for expected range of recorded ENSO events at several proxy-record locations and climates; 3) a paleoclimate data-model comparison of ENSO at similar spatial scales (downscaled model outputs).  These products will be useful for the paleoclimate communities, and for weather forecasting and risk prediction-associated with ENSO events- communities. The researcher will establish a collaboration with the national meteorology and hydrology service in Peru and develop an online course on modeling and statistics of climate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview
The El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) profoundly affects global weather patterns, economies, and ecosystems, particularly in the tropical Pacific. However, interpreting past ENSO behavior and its impacts from paleoclimate records has been challenging due to limitations in coarse-resolution climate models and reanalysis products. These tools fail to capture the local and regional atmospheric processes critical for understanding ENSO variability in areas with complex terrains. This project developed a novel approach combining high-resolution dynamical modeling, statistical modeling, and paleoclimate data to enhance our understanding of ENSO impacts on key locations across the Pacific. By bridging the gap between global climate models and local paleoclimate records, this work contributes to more accurate reconstructions of past ENSO activity and better predictions of its future impacts.

Key Findings and Intellectual Merit

ENSO diversity, characterized by variations in event types, was shown to produce distinct hydroclimate impacts that traditional indices used to measure the strength of ENSO events fail to fully capture. This diversity, encompassing Eastern Pacific (EP), Central Pacific (CP), and Coastal (COA) events, is critical for understanding past ENSO behavior and improving model performance. Coastal El Niño (COA) events emerged as critical drivers of extreme precipitation in the eastern Pacific, often coinciding with central Pacific La Niña conditions. These findings resolve conflicting paleo-ENSO records from different Pacific regions, emphasizing the significance of COAs in paleoclimate interpretations. Over the Holocene, the project revealed that Eastern Pacific (EP) ENSO events increased in frequency, while Central Pacific (CP) and COA events declined. These shifts, alongside stronger ENSO teleconnections in the eastern Pacific, resulted in intensified impacts and variable hydroclimate conditions in the Pacific.

The role of external forcings, such as volcanic eruptions, in shaping the frequency of ENSO flavors was also elucidated. Volcanic eruptions were linked to an increased frequency of COA events, with Southern Hemisphere wave trains identified as potential triggers. Additionally, the project uncovered a novel pathway for coastal El Niño development, driven by competing zonal wind anomalies in the eastern and central-western Pacific. These findings underscore the intricate interplay between regional and basin-scale dynamics in ENSO variability.

The project also contributed to the development of a convolutional neural network (CNN) forecasting system to predict ENSO diversity indices. This system improved prediction skill for strong EP events and incorporated explainable AI diagnostics to better understand the underlying drivers of ENSO variability. By analyzing historical and simulated data, the new forecasting system provided actionable insights for predicting extreme El Niño events and managing extreme precipitation and heat impacts.

Historical investigations, such as the 1930s “Galápagos Affair,” showcased ENSO’s far-reaching societal impacts. Prolonged La Niña conditions during this period led to severe droughts, illustrating how historical ENSO events shaped human resilience and adaptation.

The project also developed a pseudo-paleo modeling framework to simulate ENSO-driven hydroclimate changes over the past 21,000 years. Idealized experiments further isolated ENSO variability’s influence, offering insights into its impacts under varying climatic conditions. High-resolution simulations of the atmospheric response to representative ENSO events, including EP, CP, and COA types revealed key processes influencing extreme precipitation and humid-heat extremes.

The relationship between ENSO diversity and heat extremes, particularly wet-bulb temperature (Tw), was examined through expanded simulations and an analysis focusing on so-called global warming targets, that is discrete levels of additional global warming. CP events were found to exacerbate humid heat across most high-risk regions, while EP events had more localized effects. Under future warming scenarios, both ENSO types dramatically increased population exposure to dangerous Tw levels, emphasizing the importance of accurate seasonal climate prediction.

Broader Impacts
The project’s findings significantly advance ENSO risk prediction, providing critical insights for early warning systems addressing extreme precipitation and heat in vulnerable regions. Research collaborations strengthened local expertise in climate modeling and statistical analysis, fostering long-term research capacity.

Through this work, undergraduate and graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and faculty gained advanced skills in climate modeling, statistical analysis, and interdisciplinary collaboration. These training efforts positioned them for leadership roles in atmospheric sciences, and advanced their careers.

Results were widely disseminated through publications, workshops, and international conferences, broadening understanding of ENSO impacts in the scientific community. Practical applications of these findings inform resource management and disaster preparedness in regions like Hawaii and the eastern Pacific.

Significance for Society
ENSO events influence weather extremes, food security, water resources, and economic stability worldwide. This project’s approaches provide a clearer picture of how ENSO events manifest regionally and locally, aiding efforts to anticipate and mitigate their effects. By fostering research collaboration and training the next generation of scientists, the work ensures enduring benefits for both scientific advancement and community resilience.
